papers.title: GENERATIVE ADVERSARIAL REVIEWS: WHEN LLMS BECOME THE CRITIC
papers.abstract: The peer review process is fundamental to scientific progress, determining which papers meet the quality standards for publication. Yet, the rapid growth of scholarly production and increasing specialization in knowledge areas strain traditional scientific feedback mechanisms. In light of this, we introduce Generative Agent Reviewers (GAR), leveraging LLM-empowered agents to simulate faithful peer reviewers. To enable generative reviewers, we design an architecture that extends a large language model with memory capabilities and equips agents with reviewer personas derived from historical data. Central to this approach is a graph-based representation of manuscripts, condensing content and logically organizing information -linking ideas with evidence and technical details. GAR's review process leverages external knowledge to evaluate paper novelty, followed by detailed assessment using the graph representation and multi-round assessment. Finally, a meta-reviewer aggregates individual reviews to predict the acceptance decision. Our experiments demonstrate that GAR performs comparably to human reviewers in providing detailed feedback and predicting paper outcomes. Beyond mere performance comparison, we conduct insightful experiments, such as evaluating the impact of reviewer expertise and examining fairness in reviews. By offering early expert-level feedback, typically restricted to a limited group of researchers, GAR democratizes access to transparent and in-depth evaluation.

papers.title: Belief Graphs with Reasoning Zones: Structure, Dynamics, and Epistemic Activation
papers.abstract: Belief systems are rarely globally consistent, yet effective reasoning often persists locally. We propose a novel graph-theoretic framework that cleanly separates credibility-external, a priori trust in sources-from confidence-an internal, emergent valuation induced by network structure. Beliefs are nodes in a directed, signed, weighted graph whose edges encode support and contradiction. Confidence is obtained by a contractive propagation process that mixes a stated prior with structure-aware influence and guarantees a unique, stable solution. Within this dynamics, we define reasoning zones: high-confidence, structurally balanced subgraphs on which classical inference is safe despite global contradictions. We provide a near-linear procedure that seeds zones by confidence, tests balance using a parity-based coloring, and applies a greedy, locality-preserving repair with Jaccard de-duplication to build a compact atlas. To model belief change, we introduce shock updates that locally downscale support and elevate targeted contradictions while preserving contractivity via a simple backtracking rule. Re-propagation yields localized reconfiguration-zones may shrink, split, or collapse-without destabilizing the entire graph. We outline an empirical protocol on synthetic signed graphs with planted zones, reporting zone recovery, stability under shocks, and runtime. The result is a principled foundation for contradiction-tolerant reasoning that activates classical logic precisely where structure supports it.

papers.title: New Advances in the Pharmacology and Toxicology of Lithium: A Neurobiologically Oriented Overview
Can we increase the speed and efficacy of antidepressant treatments? Part II. Glutamatergic and RNA interference strategies
papers.filename: 2018 Artigas et al Eur Neuropsychopharmacology part II .pdf
papers.abstract: In the second part we focus on two treatment strategies that may overcome the main limitations of current antidepressant drugs. First, we review the experimental and clinical evidence supporting the use of glutamatergic drugs as fast-acting antidepressants. Secondly, we review the involvement of microRNAs in the pathophysiology of major depressive disorder (MDD) and the use of small RNAs (e.g.., small interfering RNAs or siRNAs) to knockdown serotonergic genes and induce antidepressant-like responses in experimental animals. The development of glutamatergic agents is a promising venue for antidepressant drug development, given the antidepressant properties of the non-competitive NMDA receptor antagonist ketamine. Its unique properties appear to result from the activation of AMPA receptors by a metabolite [(2S,6S;2R,6R)-hydroxynorketamine (HNK)] and mTOR signaling. These effects increase synaptogenesis in prefrontal cortical pyramidal neurons and enhance serotonergic neurotransmission via descending inputs to the raphe nuclei. This view is supported by the cancellation of ketamine's antidepressant-like effects by inhibition of serotonin synthesis. We also review existing evidence supporting the involvement of microRNA (miRNA) in MDD and the preclinical use of RNA interference (RNAi) strategies to target genes involved in antidepressant response. Many miRNAs have been associated to MDD, some of which -e.g., miR-135-target genes involved in antidepressant actions. Likewise, we review the use of SSRI-conjugated siRNA (small interfering RNA) to evoke faster and/or more effective antidepressant-like responses. Intranasal application of sertraline-conjugated siRNAs directed to 5-HT1A receptors and SERT evoked much faster changes of pre-and postsynaptic antidepressant markers than those produced by fluoxetine.

content.reasoning: This is a core claim summarizing the paper's central thesis about lithium's mechanism of action across multiple cellular pathways.
content.rephrased_claim: Lithium exerts regulatory effects on diverse cellular pathways within the brain that are crucial for neuroplasticity and neuroprotection, including neurotrophic response, ER stress, UPR, autophagy, oxidative stress, mitochondrial function, and inflammation.

content.reasoning: This is a core mechanistic claim proposing that lithium's diverse effects are fundamentally mediated by two key molecular targets.
content.rephrased_claim: Lithium's wide range of intracellular responses may be secondary to two key effects: inhibition of GSK3 and IMPase, dysregulation of which has been implicated in diverse neuropathological conditions.

content.reasoning: This is a core claim establishing a specific molecular mechanism by which lithium acts as a therapeutic agent in neurodegenerative diseases.
content.rephrased_claim: The promotion of autophagy is the primary molecular mechanism explaining lithium's protective effects in neurodegenerative diseases.

content.reasoning: This claim proposes a specific mechanistic pathway for lithium's autophagy-enhancing effects that differs from conventional understanding.
content.rephrased_claim: Lithium's signaling pathway as an autophagy enhancer operates through an mTOR-independent pathway involving IP3 signaling.

content.reasoning: This claim summarizes the mechanistic understanding of how ketamine works as an antidepressant, which is a core scientific insight reviewed in the paper about glutamatergic antidepressant strategies.
content.rephrased_claim: Ketamine's antidepressant properties result from activation of AMPA receptors by its metabolite hydroxynorketamine (HNK) and mTOR signaling, rather than NMDA receptor antagonism alone.

content.reasoning: This describes the neurobiological mechanism through which ketamine produces its antidepressant effects, representing a key scientific understanding about how glutamatergic drugs work.
content.rephrased_claim: Ketamine's antidepressant effects are mediated through increased synaptogenesis in prefrontal cortical pyramidal neurons and enhanced serotonergic neurotransmission via descending inputs to the raphe nuclei.

content.reasoning: This claim establishes a specific relationship between a microRNA and depression-related mechanisms, which is a core insight about the role of miRNAs in depression.
content.rephrased_claim: MicroRNA-135 (miR-135) targets genes involved in antidepressant actions and is associated with major depressive disorder.

content.reasoning: This is an original contribution of the paper demonstrating a novel RNA interference strategy that achieves more rapid antidepressant effects than conventional treatments.
content.rephrased_claim: Intranasal application of sertraline-conjugated siRNAs targeting 5-HT1A receptors and SERT produces faster changes in antidepressant markers than traditional SSRI treatment with fluoxetine.

content.reasoning: This claim describes a specific neurobiological finding about the role of dynorphin in depression, establishing a relationship between this neuropeptide system and depressive behaviors.
content.rephrased_claim: Knockdown of prodynorphin in the rat nucleus accumbens reduces depressive-like behavior without affecting anxiety-like behavior.

content.reasoning: This claim proposes a unifying mechanism across different antidepressant interventions, representing a core insight about convergent pathways in antidepressant action.
content.rephrased_claim: Homer1a expression in the medial prefrontal cortex represents a final common pathway mediating the antidepressant effects of various treatments including sleep deprivation, imipramine, and ketamine.

content.reasoning: This claim establishes a region-specific relationship between BDNF and depression, providing anatomical specificity to the neurotrophic hypothesis of depression.
content.rephrased_claim: BDNF reduction specifically in the dentate gyrus, but not the CA3 subfield of the hippocampus, decreases neurogenesis and causes depressive-like behaviors.

content.reasoning: This is a core interpretive claim of the paper about the significance of ketamine for challenging existing paradigms and opening new directions in antidepressant development.
content.rephrased_claim: Ketamine represents a paradigm shift in antidepressant drug development by demonstrating that rapid-acting antidepressants more efficacious than monoamine reuptake blockers can be developed through non-monoaminergic mechanisms.

content.reasoning: This is an original contribution describing a novel approach to using RNA interference for antidepressant treatment that overcomes key technical limitations.
content.rephrased_claim: SSRI-conjugated siRNAs delivered intranasally to serotonergic neurons can elicit rapid and robust antidepressant-like effects, solving the delivery and targeting challenges of RNA interference strategies for depression treatment.

content.observation_summary: Each run on Llama-3.1 (8b) took approximately 20 minutes using a single NVIDIA A100 40G GPU
content.quantitative_details: Runtime: ~20 minutes per run; Hardware: single NVIDIA A100 40G GPU; Results averaged over 20 independent runs

content.observation_summary: GAR's F1 score of 0.66 was significantly higher than the 0.49 achieved by human reviewers in the NeurIPS 2023 consistency study, with statistical significance confirmed by paired t-tests at 95% confidence level (p < 0.002)
content.quantitative_details: F1 scores: GAR = 0.66, Human reviewers = 0.49; p < 0.002 in paired t-tests at 95% confidence

content.observation_summary: GAR with threshold-based meta-reviewer (GAR>) exhibited significantly superior performance compared to vanilla GAR in predicting paper acceptance
content.quantitative_details: Threshold set at score of 6 (Weak Accept category from ICLR)

content.observation_summary: Neural Network-Optimized Persona achieved the highest accuracy at 0.74 on ICLR 23, followed by historical data initialization at 0.70, while random selection achieved 0.64
content.quantitative_details: Accuracy on ICLR 23: Neural Network-Optimized = 0.74, Historical initialization = 0.70, Random selection = 0.64

content.observation_summary: Graph-based representation (community descriptors) achieved higher F1-scores compared to node-edge representations and raw text in predicting paper acceptance
content.quantitative_details: Three input types tested: (1) community descriptors, (2) node-edge representations, (3) raw text

content.observation_summary: GAR demonstrated consistent scores between 1 and 10, with ability to accept high-quality papers (score >7) and strongly reject papers (3) that did not meet quality standards
content.quantitative_details: Score range: 1-10; acceptance threshold: >7; rejection threshold: 3

content.observation_summary: Expert-level reviewers achieved the highest accuracy and consistency in assessments, approaching the level expected of human experts, while novice and intermediate reviewers produced reasonably accurate but less consistent assessments
content.quantitative_details: Three expertise levels tested: Novice, Intermediate, and Expert

content.observation_summary: GAR demonstrated high Pearson correlation coefficients with human reviewers across all criteria (soundness, presentation, and contribution), with especially strong alignment on soundness and presentation aspects
content.quantitative_details: Pearson correlation coefficients measured on 1,000 papers from ICLR 2023; scores on scale from 1 (Poor) to 4 (Excellent)

content.observation_summary: GAR significantly outperformed AI-Scientist in generating reviews that align closely with human feedback, as evaluated by GPT-4o using a 5-point Likert scale
content.quantitative_details: 5-point Likert scale used for evaluation, where higher scores indicate stronger resemblance to human reviewers

content.observation_summary: GPT-4o achieved the highest human-likeness scores with a mean of 4.11  0.10 on ICLR 2023, followed by GPT-4o-mini at 3.99  0.09, Mistral-7b Instruct at 3.68  0.11, and Llama-3.1 (8b) at 3.64  0.12
content.quantitative_details: Mean scores  standard deviation on ICLR 2023: GPT-4o = 4.11  0.10, GPT-4o-mini = 3.99  0.09, Mistral-7b = 3.68  0.11, Llama-3.1 (8b) = 3.64  0.12

content.observation_summary: Llama-3.1 (70b), despite its larger size, did not consistently outperform smaller models in review generation human-likeness

content.observation_summary: GPT-4o exhibited significantly higher F1-score in acceptance prediction compared to other foundation models, with statistical significance confirmed by t-test (p < 0.05)

content.observation_summary: Llama-3.1 models, particularly the 70b variant, demonstrated only modest gains despite larger size, indicating diminishing returns for increased model complexity in the acceptance prediction task

content.observation_summary: Response at 24 hours was greater with ketamine than with midazolam (active placebo control) in treatment-resistant depression
content.quantitative_details: 24 h measurement timepoint

content.observation_summary: 27% of patients treated with a single intravenous dose of ketamine (0.5 mg/kg) maintained their antidepressant response 4 weeks post-treatment
content.quantitative_details: 27% sustained response rate at 4 weeks, 0.5 mg/kg ketamine dose

content.observation_summary: Intravenous ketamine infusion (0.5 mg/kg over 40 min) evoked a robust and persistent antidepressant effect in 9 patients with treatment-resistant unipolar or bipolar depression after the disappearance of the initial psychotomimetic phase, with maximal effects observed at 72 hours post-infusion
content.quantitative_details: 9 patients, 0.5 mg/kg ketamine dose, 40 min infusion, maximal effects at 72 h

content.observation_summary: Ketamine infusion evoked an antidepressant response in 71% of treatment-resistant depressive (TRD) unipolar and bipolar patients
content.quantitative_details: 71% response rate

content.observation_summary: Significant improvement occurred as soon as 110 minutes after the beginning of ketamine infusion and remained for up to 7 days, with maximal antidepressant effects occurring after 24 hours of infusion
content.quantitative_details: Significant improvement at 110 min, maximal effects at 24 h, duration up to 7 days

content.observation_summary: Low-dose ketamine (0.2 mg/kg, i.v., infusion in 1-2 min) produced very robust reduction of severity in 14 emergency depressed patients with marked suicidal ideation
content.quantitative_details: 14 patients, 0.2 mg/kg ketamine dose, 1-2 min infusion time

content.observation_summary: Among responders to repeated ketamine infusions (up to six i.v. infusions, 3 times weekly over 12 days), the median time to relapse was 18 days
content.quantitative_details: Median time to relapse: 18 days, up to 6 infusions, 3 times weekly over 12 days

content.observation_summary: The antidepressant response at 4 hours after ketamine infusion was highly predictive of a sustained response to subsequent infusions
content.quantitative_details: 4 hr predictive timepoint

content.observation_summary: Intranasal ketamine administration (single dose of 50 mg) evoked a significant improvement in depressive symptoms 24 hours after ketamine, compared to placebo
content.quantitative_details: 50 mg intranasal dose, significant improvement at 24 h

content.observation_summary: Lanicemine (AZD6765), a low-affinity NMDA receptor antagonist, showed a comparable onset of antidepressant action yet a lower response rate than ketamine at 80 minutes post-administration
content.quantitative_details: 80 min measurement timepoint, lower response rate than ketamine

content.observation_summary: Lanicemine lacked psychotomimetic action, suggesting that antidepressant effects are not associated with the psychotomimetic action
Pretreatment serine plasma concentrations were significantly lower in ketamine responder patients than in non-responders
content.quantitative_details: Significantly lower serine in responders vs non-responders

content.observation_summary: Serum vitamin B12 concentration was significantly higher in bipolar patients responding to ketamine
content.quantitative_details: Significantly higher vitamin B12 in ketamine responders

content.observation_summary: No differences were found in the levels of homocysteine (a NMDA receptor agonist) in ketamine responders versus non-responders, despite the role of vitamin B12 in its metabolism
Magnetoencephalography revealed that increased activity in the anterior cingulate cortex in response to the presentation of affectively-charged stimuli predicted antidepressant response to ketamine
Ketamine significantly increased plasma BDNF levels in responder patients 240 minutes after infusion
content.quantitative_details: Significant increase at 240 min post-infusion in responders

content.observation_summary: MDD patients with the Val/Val BDNF allele at rs6265 were more likely to exhibit enhanced antidepressant response to ketamine than Met carriers
content.quantitative_details: Val/Val genotype at rs6265 associated with better ketamine response vs Met carriers

content.observation_summary: Only patients responding to ketamine exhibited a simultaneous elevation of plasma BDNF levels and early slow wave activity (SWA), suggesting this effect may be associated with the rapid antidepressant effects of ketamine

content.method_summary: A four-phase LLM-agent pipeline (GAR framework) that simulates peer review through graph-based manuscript representation, reviewer persona selection, multi-round evaluation by 3-6 independent agents, and meta-review aggregation, validated against human reviews from ICLR 2023 dataset

structured_method_description.study_subject: Automated peer review generation for scientific papers using LLM-empowered agents
structured_method_description.observed_outcomes: Generated numerical scores (soundness, presentation, contribution, overall, confidence), lists of strengths and weaknesses, and predicted acceptance outcomes (accept/reject) compared against human reviewer assessments
structured_method_description.manipulated_conditions: Four-phase pipeline design including: (1) graph-based manuscript representation, (2) reviewer selection and persona initialization, (3) multi-round independent reviewer evaluation by 3-6 agents, and (4) meta-review aggregation
structured_method_description.control_or_reference_point: Human reviewer scores and decisions from the ICLR 2023 dataset (3,797 papers) obtained from OpenReview
structured_method_description.study_design_or_method_class: LLM-based agent simulation with multi-phase pipeline evaluation

content.method_summary: A comparative experiment testing three reviewer persona selection strategies (random, historical data initialization, neural network-optimized) for LLM-based peer review agents, measuring their accuracy in predicting paper acceptance decisions against the ICLR 2023 dataset
